text: The beauty to founders is they don't need help in the middle. You can be 10 times better in the middle than any sales rep at your bigger competitor. If you're running, I am just making up CRM, but if you're running a new CRM startup, you can run circles around 98% of the sales reps at Salesforce or HubSpot. They have the brand, they have the partners, they have the integrations, but they cannot answer the questions you can answer.
speaker: Jason Lemkin
context: Lenny asks Jason to clarify what he means by 'middlers' in sales conversations. Jason explains that founders are naturally good at the middle part of sales conversations - they can expertly discuss their product and solve customer problems, even if they're not great at opening or closing deals. He argues that founders have a huge advantage over sales reps at bigger competitors because they have deep product knowledge that most sales reps lack.
text_ko: 창업자에게 멋진 점은 중간에 도움을 받을 필요가 없다는 거예요. 당신이 경쟁사보다 중간 단계에서 10배 더 나은 성과를 낼 수 있어요. 예를 들어, 새로운 CRM 스타트업을 운영하고 있다면, Salesforce나 HubSpot의 98% 영업사원보다 훨씬 더 앞서 나갈 수 있어요. 그들은 브랜드도 있고, 파트너도 있고, 통합도 되어 있지만, 당신이 대답할 수 있는 질문에는 답을 못해요.
text_zh: 创始人的优势就在于中间环节不需要别人帮忙。在中间这块，你可以比大竞争对手的任何销售都强十倍。打个比方，假如你在做一个新的CRM创业项目，你绝对可以秒杀Salesforce或者HubSpot那边98%的销售。他们是有品牌、有合作伙伴、有各种集成，但是你能回答的问题，他们根本答不上来。
text_es: Lo genial de los fundadores es que no necesitan ayuda en el proceso intermedio. Puedes ser 10 veces mejor en esa parte que cualquier vendedor de tu competencia más grande. Si estás manejando, no sé, digamos un CRM, pero si tienes una startup nueva de CRM, puedes darles mil vueltas al 98% of los vendedores de Salesforce o HubSpot. Ellos tienen la marca, tienen los socios, tienen las integraciones, pero no pueden contestar las preguntas que tú sí puedes contestar.

text: Those first couple reps have to be people you would buy your own product from. That's it. Now we can talk about other criteria. We can talk about normalizing for deal size. We can talk about industry expertise. We can talk about all this kind of stuff, but when you go out as a first time founder and interview 30 reps, and you're going to have to interview 30, and 20 are just going to break your brain because they don't do any work and they don't do any prep and they didn't even go to your website.
speaker: Jason Lemkin
context: Lenny asks about signs that indicate it's time to hire your first salesperson. Jason shares his key hiring criterion for the first two sales reps - they must be people you would actually buy your own product from. He explains that most founders will need to interview around 30 candidates, with 20 being completely unprepared and only 1-2 being truly magical hires who understand the product deeply.
text_ko: 처음 몇 명의 영업 담당자(reps)는 당신이 ‘이 사람한테서 직접 제품을 살 것 같다’고 느낄 정도의 사람들이어야 해요. 그게 전부예요. 그다음에 다른 기준들을 얘기할 수 있죠. 거래 규모(deal size)를 보정하는 문제라든가, 산업 전문성(industry expertise) 같은 것들을요. 온갖 얘기를 할 수 있지만, 첫 창업자(first-time founder)로서 나가서 30명의 영업 담당자(reps)를 인터뷰해야 한다면 — 실제로 30명을 다 인터뷰해야 할 거예요 — 그중 20명은 일을 안 하고 준비도 안 하고 심지어 웹사이트조차 안 봐서 당신을 완전히 골치 아프게 만들 거예요.
text_zh: 头几个销售(reps)必须得是那种你自己都愿意从他们那买产品的人，就这么简单。然后咱们再谈其他标准也不迟。咱们可以聊怎么按照单子大小来衡量，可以聊行业专业度，可以聊各种各样的东西，但是作为第一次创业的创始人，你出去面试30个销售(reps)的时候——而且你确实得面试30个——其中20个会直接把你气疯，因为他们啥功课都不做，啥准备都没有，连你的网站都懒得看一眼。
text_es: Esos primeros vendedores tienen que ser gente a la que tú mismo le comprarías tu producto. Así de simple. Ya después podemos hablar de otros criterios. Podemos hablar de ajustar por el tamaño del deal. Podemos hablar de experiencia en la industria. De todo ese rollo, pero cuando sales como fundador primerizo y entrevistas a 30 vendedores, y vas a tener que entrevistar a 30, te vas a dar cuenta de que 20 te van a freír la cabeza porque no hacen nada de trabajo, no se preparan para nada y ni siquiera se molestaron en ver tu página web.

text: You need two sales reps hitting quota closing deals before you're ready to hire a manager for them. Almost all VPs of sales, their job is to take you from rep three to 300, to take you from three to 300, to take something that's just starting to repeat, a script that's just starting to work, leads that are just starting to come in.
speaker: Jason Lemkin
context: Lenny asks about the appropriate level and seniority for first sales hires, specifically about the common mistake of hiring a VP of sales too early. Jason explains that you need two successful individual contributor reps before hiring a sales manager. He describes the VP of sales role as scaling from 3 to 300 reps, not finding initial product-market fit.
text_ko: 관리자를 뽑을 준비가 되려면 쿼터(quota)를 달성하고 계약을 성사시키는 영업 담당자(sales reps) 두 명이 있어야 해요. 거의 모든 영업 부사장(VP of Sales)의 역할은 영업 담당자 3명에서 300명으로 키우는 것, 즉 이제 막 반복되기 시작한 상황—효과가 나기 시작한 영업 스크립트(script)와 리드(leads)가 들어오기 시작한 상태—을 확장하는 일이에요.
text_zh: 你得先有两个销售能完成业绩指标、能成单，这时候才适合给他们配个经理。几乎所有的销售VP，他们的活儿就是带着你从第3个销售做到300个，从3个人的小团队扩展到300人，把刚开始有点起色的业务、刚开始管用的话术(script)、刚开始进来的线索(leads)真正做起规模来。
text_es: Necesitas dos vendedores que estén cumpliendo su cuota y cerrando negocios antes de estar listo para contratarles un gerente. Casi todos los VPs de ventas, su trabajo es llevarte del vendedor tres al 300, llevarte de tres a 300, tomar algo que apenas está empezando a repetirse, un guión que apenas está empezando a funcionar, prospectos (leads) que apenas están empezando a llegar.

text: If you hire a VP of sales before then, you're asking them to find product market fit to be the first rep, to be the second rep and scale it all at the same time. It's mission impossible to do all four at the same time. So that's the biggest mistake is, Lenny, I can't get sales going at my company. I can't do it, but I raised $4 million in my C+ round. I'm going to go out and hire the VP of sales. That VP of sales will not be there in eight months.
speaker: Jason Lemkin
context: Lenny continues asking about when to hire a VP of sales. Jason emphasizes why hiring a VP of sales too early always fails - you're asking one person to simultaneously discover product-market fit, be the first successful rep, train a second rep, and build scalable processes. He warns that this approach typically results in the VP leaving within eight months and burning through significant cash.
text_ko: 그 시점 이전에 영업 부사장(VP of Sales)을 뽑으면, 그 사람에게 제품-시장 적합성(product-market fit)을 찾아야 하고, 첫 영업 담당자(first rep)로 뛰어야 하고, 두 번째 영업 담당자(second rep) 역할도 하면서 동시에 조직을 확장(scale)하라고 요구하는 셈이에요. 네 가지를 한꺼번에 해내라고 하는 건 사실상 불가능해요. 그래서 가장 큰 실수는 이런 거예요. "레니, 우리 회사 영업이 안 돼요. 제가 못하겠어요. 근데 C+ 라운드(C+ round)에서 400만 달러를 모았으니 영업 부사장(VP of Sales)을 바로 뽑을게요." 그런데 그 영업 부사장은 8개월도 못 버틸 거예요.
text_zh: 如果你在那之前就招一个销售VP，那你就是让他们既要找产品市场匹配(product market fit)，又要当第一个销售，还要当第二个销售，同时还得把整个团队规模化。这四件事同时做，简直是不可能完成的任务。所以最大的错误就是，Lenny，我公司的销售搞不起来，我自己搞不定，但我C+轮融了400万美金，那我就出去招个销售VP吧。这个销售VP八个月内肯定走人。
text_es: Si contratas a un VP de ventas antes de ese momento, le estás pidiendo que encuentre el product market fit, que sea el primer vendedor, que sea el segundo vendedor y que escale todo al mismo tiempo. Es una misión imposible hacer las cuatro cosas a la vez. Ese es el error más grande: "Lenny, no logro que arranquen las ventas en mi empresa. No puedo hacerlo, pero levanté 4 millones de dólares en mi ronda C+. Voy a salir a contratar un VP de ventas." Ese VP de ventas no va a estar ahí en ocho meses.

text: Here's the mistake that 99% of founders and sales reps make. We're not really selling in B2B, we're solving problems. Our job as sales reps in SaaS is to not sell a used car, okay? We are selling a Tesla Model 3 performance. It has competition, I might not need it this week, but it's pretty darn good. Let me help you get you into that Model 3 performance today.
speaker: Jason Lemkin
context: During a discussion about interview techniques for sales reps, Jason explains the fundamental mindset shift needed in B2B sales. He argues that SaaS companies aren't selling commodities but solving meaningful problems, comparing it to selling a high-quality Tesla rather than using manipulative used car tactics. This perspective is crucial for both founders and sales reps to understand.
text_ko: 창업자랑 영업사원 중 99%가 하는 실수가 있어요. 우리는 B2B(B2B)에서 단순히 '파는' 사람이 아니라 문제를 해결하는 사람인 걸 몰라요. SaaS(SaaS)에서 영업사원으로서 우리의 역할은 중고차를 팔아치우는 게 아니에요. 우리는 테슬라 모델 3 퍼포먼스(Tesla Model 3 Performance)를 파는 거예요. 경쟁은 있겠고, 이번 주에 꼭 필요하지 않을 수도 있지만, 이건 정말 좋은 선택이에요. 오늘 제가 그 모델 3 퍼포먼스에 타실 수 있게 도와드릴게요.
text_zh: 99%的创始人和销售都犯这个错误。在B2B里，我们其实不是在卖东西，而是在解决问题。我们做SaaS销售的，不是在卖二手车，明白吧？我们卖的是特斯拉Model 3高性能版。虽然有竞争对手，我这周可能也不急着要，但这车确实够棒的。让我今天就帮你拿下这台Model 3高性能版。
text_es: Aquí está el error que comete el 99% de los fundadores y vendedores. En B2B no estamos vendiendo realmente, estamos resolviendo problemas. Nuestro trabajo como vendedores en SaaS no es vender un carro usado, ¿vale? Estamos vendiendo un Tesla Model 3 performance. Tiene competencia, puede que no lo necesite esta semana, pero está padrísimo. Déjeme ayudarle a conseguir ese Model 3 performance hoy mismo.

text: The first three months of a new rep, you're lucky if they can close as much as their take-home pay is, their OT. And so, in the really early days, my early, early day comp plan is, look, your first three months, you keep a hundred percent of what you close. Of course, that's not profitable for the business, but you've got to invest in them, right?
speaker: Jason Lemkin
context: Lenny asks about compensation and quota structure for early sales hires. Jason explains his unconventional approach of letting new reps keep 100% of what they close in their first quarter. He acknowledges this isn't immediately profitable but argues it's necessary investment to help reps get started and build confidence while learning the product.
text_ko: 신입 영업사원이 처음 세 달 동안에 성사시키는 실적이 실수령액(take-home pay), 그러니까 OT(on-target earnings)만큼 나와도 운이 좋은 거예요. 그래서 정말 초창기에는 제 보상 플랜(comp plan, compensation plan)이 이렇습니다. 보세요, 처음 세 달 동안 성사시킨 건 전부 100% 가져가세요. 물론 회사 입장에서는 이게 수익이 나는 구조는 아니지만, 그 사람들에게는 투자를 해야 해요.
text_zh: 新销售的前三个月，他们能成交的金额跟他们拿到手的工资差不多就不错了。所以在最开始那段时间，我的薪酬方案(comp plan)是这样的：头三个月，你成交多少全归你。当然这样对公司来说肯定是不赚钱的，但你得先投资培养他们，对吧？
text_es: Los primeros tres meses de un vendedor nuevo, con suerte van a cerrar ventas por lo que ganan neto, su salario base. Entonces, en los primeros días, mi plan de comisiones (comp plan) desde el inicio es: mira, tus primeros tres meses, te quedas con el cien por ciento de lo que cierres. Claro, eso no es rentable para el negocio, pero tienes que invertir en ellos, ¿no?

text: The magical thing at the high level that it compounds, if you have a self-service model, a PLG model, I actually think the number one most important metric is churn. It's going to this churn, churn, churn, churn. And when I meet any startup for investing or anything, if the churn is not top decile for a low end product, I'm always out. It's almost unsolvable.
speaker: Jason Lemkin
context: Lenny asks about product teams taking on P&L responsibilities and revenue goals. Jason discusses the importance of focusing on metrics that compound over time rather than short-term revenue optimization. He emphasizes that for PLG companies, churn is the most critical metric because high churn rates (3-4% monthly) are nearly impossible to overcome and prevent building a sustainable billion-dollar business.
text_ko: 높은 수준에서 복리처럼 불어나는 마법 같은 건, 셀프 서비스 모델(self-service model)이나 PLG 모델(PLG model)이 있을 때인데, 사실 가장 중요한 지표는 이탈률(churn)이라고 생각해요. 계속 이탈, 이탈, 이탈이에요. 그래서 투자나 미팅으로 스타트업을 만날 때 저가형 제품(low-end product)의 이탈률이 상위 10%(top decile)에 들지 않으면 저는 항상 손 떼요. 거의 해결 불가능하다고 봐요.
text_zh: 高层面上有个神奇的地方，就是复合效应。如果你做的是自助服务模式，PLG模式(product-led growth)，我觉得最重要的指标其实是流失率(churn)。就是不断地流失、流失、流失。我见任何创业公司，不管是投资还是别的，如果是低端产品但流失率不在前10%，我基本就不考虑了。这个问题几乎没法解决。
text_es: Lo increíble a alto nivel es que se compone, si tienes un modelo de autoservicio, un modelo PLG (product-led growth), yo creo que la métrica más importante de todas es el churn. Todo se reduce al churn, churn, churn, churn. Y cuando me reúno con cualquier startup para invertir o lo que sea, si el churn no está en el decil superior para un producto de gama baja, siempre paso. Es casi imposible de resolver.
